original_request: Vingroup exports software services to clients in the United States. What conditions must be satisfied to apply 0% VAT

past_responses_found.filename: FCT and VAT implications on loaned equipment-PIC Oanh Pham - MIC Nhung Le.md
past_responses_found.content:
The purchase price, in the purchase option stated in Article 15 of the Agreement, will be at a 65% discount from the list price as determined by ABC. No software and/or intellectual property will be transferred by ABC to the distributor upon the disposal of the loaned equipment.

ABC assumed all related costs of bringing the loaned equipment physically into Vietnam, including shipping costs, Valued added Tax (“VAT”) and import duties at the import stage, etc. The loaned equipment was delivered by ABC to the distributor in May 2019 with the customs declaration under A11 code for importation procedures (i.e. Import for consumption and for trading). The import VAT was declared and paid to the State Budget based on the list price of the loaned equipment at import stage.

Vietnamese Foreign Contractor Tax (“FCT”) and VAT implications on the distributor’s purchase of the loaned equipment; and

The possibility to apply the relevant tax treaty for tax exemption, where applicable
Please advise if any of the above understanding is not correct as it may materially impact our comments hereunder.
Regulatory basis
Our comments from tax regulatory perspectives herein have been prepared based on the information and documents provided by you, in accordance with the relevant regulations currently in force in Vietnam as of the reporting date.  Particularly, our comments are mainly based on the legal documents as outlined in Appendix 1.
Important note
We have been requested to advise on the Vietnamese tax regulatory implications associated with the above arrangements only. Our advice therefore only focuses on current Vietnamese tax and other regulatory regulations of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and will not take into account (i) legal implications and (ii) tax implications of jurisdictions other than Vietnam. 
Our comments are based on our understanding of the preliminary information that have been provided to us at this stage, in light of the relevant regulations currently in force in Vietnam as of the reporting date. Should there be any changes in the service structure at a later stage, we can assist in updating the comments under a separate engagement.
Our comments
FCT and VAT implications
Overview of Vietnamese taxation
Foreign Contractor Tax (“FCT”) is a comprehensive tax collection regime that applies to, amongst others, foreign business organizations, with or without permanent establishment (“PE”) in Vietnam, doing business in Vietnam or having Vietnam-sourced income on the basis of a contract, agreement or undertaking with Vietnamese organizations. Broadly, FCT is a collection mechanism for Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) and Value Add Tax (“VAT”).
Conceptually, FCT will not be applied if the goods are supplied with the place of delivery at the border gates, and without accompanied services provided in Vietnam.
For goods delivered within the territories of Vietnam, the applicable tax rates for trading activities will be applied at 1% deemed CIT and 1% dee...

past_responses_found.filename: Vietnamese tax implications on flash-title transfer transactions inside bonded warehouse.md
past_responses_found.content:
No. 2389/TCT-CS for Canon Singapore’s case, OL No. 3997/TCT-CS for Sagawa’s case and OL No. 1474/TCT-DNL for Sabic’s case);
The risk of exposing to income tax of this flash-title-transfer transaction, therefore, is considered high.
There is no clear mechanism on how to declare and pay taxes on this type of transactions under the current tax regulations. However, the taxing mechanism was guided/mentioned under the above OLs;
In practice, the policy makers are becoming well aware of this kind of business model and may insist to tax by carrying out tax audits at the bonded warehouse management or the logistics companies, on the basis that the bonded warehouse managers are required to notify the Customs Office regarding the transfer of ownership of goods stored at the bonded warehouse for management and supervision under the Customs regulations.2
The “substance over form principle” was enacted under the Law on Tax Administration 2019 which is effective from 01 July 2020, being the principle applied in tax administration to analyze transactions and business activities of taxpayers to determine the corresponding tax obligations.3
Given the above, the absence of taxing mechanism would not reduce the level of tax risk since (i) the transaction is taxable in principle and (ii) a number of OLs have confirmed taxing mechanism in practice. Since the responsibilities to withhold, declare and pay taxes rests with income payment organization (i.e.
Client TW) in practice, it is recommended that a private ruling should be obtained from the local tax authorities to confirm the tax position of the transaction and the mechanism to declare and pay taxes in Vietnam.
files_used: Vietnamese tax implications on flash-title transfer transactions inside bonded warehouse.md

past_responses_found.filename: Tax and Customs implication on goods trading via bonded warehouse.md
past_responses_found.content:
Private and confidential

Warranty / Maintenance Work in Vietnam related to the above goods supply
For the warranty which is conducted within effective period of the warranty term for free of charge and maintenance services for which ABC Company would charge their customers, ABC Company is considering either of the following options:
Option 1: ABC Company engages a local ABC company to carry out the warranty / maintenance work and would pay the local ABC company all related expenses, including visa application and salary payments, labor and health insurance expenses for the involved personnel.
Option 2: ABC Company engages a local agency to carry out the warranty / maintenance work, and would pay the local agency all related expenses, including visa application and salary payments, labor and health insurance expenses for the involved personnel.
The involved personnel are directly engaged into the employment relationship with local ABC company / local agency, but not ABC Company.
Local ABC company / local agency would issue invoices to charge fees to ABC Company, meanwhile ABC Company would directly issue the invoices to charge maintenance fee to the Vietnam customers.
KPMG’s comments
Vietnam Tax Perspective
Vietnam tax implications to ABC Company, including but not limited to Vietnam withholding tax (“WHT”), value added tax (“VAT”), personal income tax (“PIT”) obligations
WHT implications to ABC Company for M&E sales through Vietnam BWH
Vietnam tax system imposes WHT on foreign contractors who do not have a tax presence in Vietnam but earn income from Vietnam. WHT comprise of Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) and Value Added Tax (“VAT”).
Under the current regulations, a foreign contractor shall be subject to Vietnam WHT in certain cases, including but not limited to:
Foreign contractor supplying goods in Vietnam in the form of on-the-spot import and export and having income arising in Vietnam on the basis of a contract signed by such

foreign contractor with a Vietnam party or carrying out distribution of goods in Vietnam or supply of goods on international commercial terms – Incoterms whereby the seller shall bear risks relating to goods entering into the territory of Vietnam.
Foreign contractor conducting all or part of business or distribution activities for goods or provision of services in Vietnam when the foreign contractor remains the owner of the goods delivered to Vietnam party and is responsible for costs of distribution, advertising, marketing, quality of services or quality of goods delivered to Vietnam party; including the case in which a number of Vietnam parties are authorized or hired to carry out part of distribution services or other services relating to the sale of goods in Vietnam.
Pertaining to the contemplated model, we noted that ABC Company would store its goods in a BWH located in Vietnam. Upon demand request from the Vietnam customers, ABC Company would deliver the goods thereafter and the goods ownership would be transferred...

FREE TRADE AGREEMENT BETWEEN
THE SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIET NAM, OF THE ONE PART, AND THE EURASIAN
ECONOMIC UNION AND ITS MEMBER STATES,
OF THE OTHER PART
PREAMBLE
The Socialist Republic of Viet Nam (hereinafter referred to as “Viet Nam”),
of the one part, and the Republic of Armenia, the Republic of Belarus, the
Republic of Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, the Russian Federation
(hereinafter referred to as “the Member States of the Eurasian Economic
Union”), and the Eurasian Economic Union, of the other part:
RECOGNISING the importance of enhancing their longstanding and strong
friendship and the traditional multi-faceted cooperation between the Parties;
DESIRING to create favourable conditions for the development and
diversification of trade between them and for the promotion of commercial and
economic cooperation in areas of common interest on the basis of equality,
mutual benefit, non-discrimination and international law;
REAFFIRMING their respective rights and obligations under the Marrakesh
Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization and other existing
international agreements to which the Parties are party;
RECOGNISING the need to uphold the principles and practices which promote
free and unhindered trade in a stable, transparent and non-discriminatory manner;
CONVINCED that this Agreement will enhance the competitiveness of the
economies of the Parties in global markets and create conditions encouraging
economic, trade and investment relations between them;
BEING CONSCIOUS of the importance of trade facilitation in promoting
efficient and transparent procedures to reduce costs and ensure predictability;
2
EMPHASISING the complementarities of the economies of the Parties and the
significant potential to advance economic relations by further developing the
framework for trade and investment;
ACKNOWLEDGING the important role and contribution of investments in
enhancing trade and cooperation between the Parties and the need to further
promote and facilitate cooperation and greater business opportunities provided by
this Agreement;
REAFFIRMING the importance of ongoing economic cooperation initiatives
between the Parties, and agreeing to further develop the existing economic
partnership in areas where the Parties have mutual interests;
DESIRING to eliminate barriers to trade and investment between the Parties,
lower business costs and enhance economic efficiency; and
CONVINCED that joint efforts between the Parties towards an advanced free
trade agreement will develop an enhanced framework for the promotion and
development of economic and trade relations between Viet Nam and the Member
States of the Eurasian Economic Union in their common interest and for their
mutual benefit;
HAVE AGREED as follows:
3
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
ARTICLE 1.1

636
NOTE ON TARIFF RATE QUOTAS FOR EGGS EXPORTED TO VIET NAM
1. The following within-quota tariff reduction, which shall be done in three equal
annual instalments to free, shall be applied to eggs originating in the Member
States of the Eurasian Economic Union exported to Viet Nam in accordance
with this Note.
2. Viet Nam shall accord to the Member States of the Eurasian Economic Union
the total annual import quota of 8 000 dozen for eggs originating in the
Member States of the Eurasian Economic Union, which shall be separate from
the quantity of Viet Nam’s tariff rate quotas for eggs under its WTO
commitments.
3. The out-of-quota tariff rate shall be applied in accordance with the domestic
laws and regulations of Viet Nam on tariff rate quotas and pursuant to Article
2.1 of this Agreement.
4. The annual growth rate of quota quantity is five percent.

637
NOTE ON TARIFF RATE QUOTAS FOR UNMANUFACTURED TOBACCO AND
TOBACCO REFUSE EXPORTED TO VIET NAM
1. The following within-quota tariff reduction, which shall be done in five
annual instalments to free, shall be applied to unmanufactured tobacco and
tobacco refuse originating in the Member States of the Eurasian Economic
Union exported to Viet Nam in accordance with this Note.
2. Viet Nam shall accord to the Member States of the Eurasian Economic
Union the total annual import quota of 500 tonnes for unmanufactured
tobacco and tobacco refuse originating in the Member States of the Eurasian
Economic Union, which shall be in accordance with Viet Nam's
international commitments and respective domestic laws and regulations on
those tariff rate quota products.
3. The out-of-quota tariff rate shall be applied in accordance with the domestic
laws and regulations of Viet Nam on tariff rate quotas and pursuant to
Article 2.1 of this Agreement.

laws and regulations of the Eurasian Economic Union on tariff rate quotas and
pursuant to Article 2.1 of this Agreement.

Instructions for Completing Certificate of Origin (Form EAV)
The Certificate of Origin (Form EAV) and its additional sheets must be on ISO
A4 size colour paper in conformity with the specimen shown in this Annex. It
shall be made in the English language.
Unused spaces in boxes 6 through 11 shall be crossed out to prevent any
subsequent addition.
The Certificate of Origin shall:
a) be in a hard copy and in conformity with the specimen text set out in
this Annex, which shall be printed in the English language;
b) contain the minimum data required in boxes 1, 2, 4, 7 through 13;
c) bear a signature of an authorised signatory and official seal of the
authorised body and security features. The signature shall be
handwritten and official seal shall not be a facsimile.
Box 1: Enter details of the exporter of the goods: business name, address and
country.
Box 2: Enter details of the importer of the goods (obligatory) and consignee (if
known): business name, address and country.
Box 3: Enter details of transportation (as far as known) such as departure
(shipment) date, means of transport (vessel, aircraft, et
